This means that humans are obligated to strive to find the benefits and uses of Allah's creation for themselves. The key to everything is the willingness to strive and the desire to know some of Allah's knowledge. This has been started by humans since ancient times until now, so that the longer the earth is inhabited by humans, the more of Allah's knowledge is known by humans and the benefits of the universe. All of this is for the sake of human life and existence. However, only a small portion of Allah's knowledge has been known by humans.

Allah's creations in the heavens such as the sun, moon, stars, clouds, wind, rainwater, and His creations on earth such as plants, animals, mountains, oceans, and others, are all created by Him not only as a mercy and grace to humans but also contain signs of His power and greatness, which show that the creator is the One and Only God. There is no other God besides Him, who always protects His creation and is not worthy of being associated with anything. Such a conclusion can only be obtained by a servant of Allah who makes careful observations, uses a sound mind, and is willing to seek the truth.

If someone is willing to pay attention to the universe, willing to pay attention to the relationship of unity between one type of creature and another, then he will certainly come to the conclusion that each unity is related to one another, cannot be separated or stand alone. It can be seen in the process of rain formation, which is closely related to the existence of the sea, the existence of mountains, the heat emitted by the sun, the existence of wind, and so on. Likewise, the rotation of the wind direction is determined by many things, such as the existence of clouds, mountains, and solar heat.

Ships sailing at sea require wind or fuel such as coal or oil. The higher a person's knowledge, the more he knows about the relationship between one creature and other creatures. The moon cannot release its trajectory from the earth, as if it were captured by the earth, and so too the earth and other planets are prisoners of the sun. The planets always orbit the sun in their respective orbits. Furthermore, the sun and the planets that follow cannot break away from a larger unity, namely the Milky Way Galaxy. Finally, the Milky Way Galaxy together with other galaxies are also bound to a certain arrangement. So with thought and research, one will come to the conclusion that the creator must be the One and Only God, the All-Powerful.

The verse above, as with many similar verses, shows how Allah subjects the heavens and the earth for humans. As is known, nature has physical properties, all of which are Allah's decrees, *Sunatullah*, and are a manifestation of the submission of nature. For example, the earth has physical properties such as electricity, magnetism, elasticity, and mass density. From these physical properties, humans, especially earth scientists, can study the earth, even far into the earth. By utilizing the elasticity of the earth, humans can capture earthquake waves that propagate within the earth and know the physical characteristics of the earth's layers through which they pass. With these earthquake waves, humans can know the layers of the earth from the top to the earth's core, which is about 6000 km below us. In practical use, the search for petroleum uses this property of earth elasticity, namely by sending waves whose source comes from "artificial earthquakes", which in the past used dynamite.

In the interior of the earth there is the earth's core, the outer part of which is liquid. It is this core that causes the earth to have a strong magnetic field that plays an important role in maintaining the continuity of life. Spreading far above the surface, this magnetic field protects the earth from damaging radiation originating from outer space. Radiation from stars other than the sun cannot pass through this shield, which is called the Van Allen Belt. This shield stretches to about 18,000 km from the earth, protecting this ball from deadly energy. In a practical aspect, by knowing this magnetic property, earth scientists develop exploration methods for both minerals and petroleum.

The statement that creation was not done for fun is often put forward in many verses of the Al-Qur'an. This statement guarantees that the earth is habitable. The earth is made easy by Allah to be inhabited by mankind.

"He is the One Who has made the earth subservient to you, so walk upon its slopes and eat from His provision." (al-Mulk/67: 15)
text.14:
Al-Wahidi and al-Qusyairi narrated from Ibn 'Abbas that this verse was revealed in connection with a problem that occurred between 'Umar bin al-Khaththab and Abdullah bin Ubay in the battle of Bani Musthalik. They stopped at a well called Al-Muraisi', then Abdullah sent a young man to fetch water, but the young man took a very long time to return. Abdullah bin Ubay asked the young man why he took so long to return. The young man replied that Umar was sitting by the well. He did not allow anyone to take water before he filled the girbai (water container made of leather) of the Prophet Muhammad saw, the girbai of Abu Bakar, and the girbai of Umar's former slave. Then Abdullah bin Ubay said, "We and they are no different from the saying: Fatten your dog, and it will eat you." Then Abdullah's words reached Umar. He became angry and drew his sword to kill Abdullah bin Ubay, then this verse was revealed, softening Umar's heart.

Furthermore, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah saw and his followers to be broad-minded in facing the attitudes of the polytheists and to forgive their actions of mocking the verses of Allah. They are people who oppose Allah and are not afraid of His threats.

From this verse, we understand the high moral values that the Islamic religion teaches its adherents, namely, to be broad-minded and forgive those who have acted unkindly towards them or tried to destroy their religion. Forgiving the mistakes of family, colleagues, neighbors, and acquaintances can be easily done by someone, but being broad-minded and forgiving the actions of people who always want to harm oneself and one's religion at every opportunity requires greatness of soul.

This verse teaches and educates Muslims to be broad-minded, forgiving, and magnanimous in facing everything in their lives.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains why the Messenger of Allah saw and his followers must be broad-minded and forgive the actions of the Quraysh who mocked the verses of Allah. The reason is that Allah will give them a fitting reward according to their deeds.
text.15:
In this verse, Allah explains that each person will receive a recompense according to their deeds in the world. So, whoever among His servants obeys all His commands and avoids all His prohibitions with full sincerity and awareness, then the result is for themselves. They will obtain a place of return full of enjoyment. Conversely, whoever denies His commands and does not cease from His prohibitions, then the bad consequences as a recompense for their actions will befall themselves. They will obtain a bad, humiliating place of return, and a very severe punishment in Hell.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that only to Allah is the return of all creatures, not to anyone else. All of them will be gathered in the Padang Mahsyar (the Plain of Gathering) to receive a just decision from Allah. Among them are those whose faces will be radiant with joy because they will meet Allah, whom they always hoped for during their life in the world. They are certain that Allah loves His servants who are steadfast, patient, and always submissive and obedient to Him. Conversely, there are also those whose faces are gloomy because their hearts are full of fear and regret. They are afraid to meet Allah because they will receive His wrath and will feel a very painful torment in Hell.
text.16:
In this verse, Allah explains that the Children of Israel (Bani Israil) were given the Torah, the ability to understand religion, prophethood, abundant sustenance, and superiority over other nations in their time.

The blessings that Allah gave to the Children of Israel at that time were commensurate with their attitude and efforts in upholding the religion of Allah. Therefore, the superiority given was also a superiority in this world and the hereafter. In this verse, six kinds of blessings that were given to them are mentioned, namely:

First: The Torah.

This book was revealed to Prophet Musa (Moses). In it, there are guidance, lessons, and provisions that can guide the Children of Israel to the right path. This book was specifically revealed by Allah for the Children of Israel.

Second: The ability to understand the religion of Allah.

With this ability, Musa, Harun (Aaron), along with the leaders of their people, could explain the disputes that occurred among their people, and with this ability, they could also explain the religion of Allah to the Children of Israel well.

Third: Prophethood

Many of the messengers and prophets sent by Allah were appointed from the Children of Israel; some of them were only prophets, such as Prophet Khidr, and some were prophets and messengers, such as Musa, Harun, Ayyub (Job), and others, and there were also prophets and messengers who were appointed from among them who, in addition to serving as prophets and messengers, also served as heads of state, such as Prophet Daud (David) and Prophet Sulaiman (Solomon). Thus, worldly and religious power was gathered in them.

Fourth: Abundant sustenance

The Children of Israel were granted a golden age during the reigns of Prophet Daud and his son Sulaiman. Many stories tell of the greatness and glory of the Children of Israel during the reigns of these two, father and son. The power and wisdom of Prophet Daud and Prophet Sulaiman are explained in the Al-Qur'an. What the Children of Israel achieved at that time was not obtained by other nations of their time.

Fifth: Their superiority over other nations in their time, namely during the time of Prophet Daud and Prophet Sulaiman.

Sixth: Allah had given them laws and teachings that were reinforced with miracles. This encouraged them to unite, and they did not disagree except for minor disagreements that did not cause harm. However, when knowledge came to them, they disagreed, as stated in Allah's words above. The disagreement among them arose after clear *hujjah* (arguments) came, due to competition for leadership and envy among them.

Regarding the superiority obtained by the Children of Israel, Ibn 'Abbas once said, "There is no one among the people in this world who is loved by Allah more than them." Allah has shown signs of His power that can be seen, heard, and understood by them. They also followed all of Allah's guidance. Such was the state of the Children of Israel at that time.
text.17:
In this verse, the sixth favor that Allah bestowed upon the Children of Israel is explained: that Allah gave them the ability to understand the proofs and explanations concerning religion. These explanations sometimes took the form of laws, warnings, and sometimes miracles. All were understood and implemented well, so that their lives became good, no disputes occurred among them, and their social bonds became strong. Consequently, they were able to accomplish many great endeavors at that time.

Actually, the above provision does not only apply to the Children of Israel, but also applies to all nations who are willing to carry out Allah's commands and avoid His prohibitions, and who submit, obey, and surrender to Him. If so, the happiness obtained will not only be worldly happiness, but also the happiness of the Hereafter. It is as if with this verse, Allah is reminding mankind to emulate the life of the Children of Israel in the past.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains the reasons for the disputes that arose among the later generations of the Children of Israel. Their prophets in the past had explained that a final Prophet would come later, who would be sent to all mankind. That Prophet would be a descendant of Ibrahim from his son Ismail. After the Prophet in question came and provided explanations in accordance with the explanations conveyed by their prophets in the past, they denied him and did not believe in him. This envy arose because the Prophet who was sent was not from the descendants of Ishaq, and they considered that the descendants of Ishaq were more noble than the descendants of Ismail, even though both were half-brothers (sons of Prophet Ibrahim). Therefore, it was not fitting for the last prophet and messenger to be appointed from his descendants. Allah says:

"And they (the People of the Scripture) did not become divided until after knowledge had come to them - out of jealousy among themselves." (ash-Shura/42: 14)

Regarding the matters they disputed, Allah will give His decision on the Day of Judgment and will explain the real reasons that caused the disputes among them. At that time, their envy and jealousy will be clearly visible, leading to group fanaticism, so that the blessings that should have been gratefully received instead made them arrogant and conceited.
text.18: Then Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) not to be influenced by the attitude of the Quraysh, because Allah had established the matters of the Sharia which must be used as a guide in establishing religious matters through revelation. Therefore, the regulations contained in the revelation are what must be followed, and one must not follow the desires of those who do not know. The Sharia brought by the previous messengers and the Sharia brought by Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) are the same in essence and reality, both based on *tauhid* (monotheism), guiding people to the right path, realizing the benefit of society, enjoining good and forbidding evil. If there are differences, then the differences are not fundamental issues, only in the implementation of worship and its methods. This is adjusted to the circumstances, place and time.
text.19:
In this verse, Allah explains that the polytheists do not know Allah's law (syariat) and do not acknowledge His Oneness. Therefore, they will not be able to reject or avoid Allah's punishment that will be inflicted upon them in the afterlife.

Then it is explained that the polytheists help each other in committing evil and disobedience. It is emphasized that their deceit is carried out by conspiring to obstruct and damage the religion of Islam and divide the Muslims. They can do this only during their life in the world, while in the afterlife they will not be able to do so. On that day, no one can help another and cannot bear the sins of another; each person is responsible for their own actions.

At the end of the verse, Allah affirms that He is the protector of the righteous (orang yang bertakwa). The piety (takwa) that they perform to seek Allah's pleasure is rewarded by Him with manifold rewards in the afterlife.
text.20:
In this verse, Allah explains that the Qur'an is a guide for human life, a guidance and mercy bestowed upon His servants who believe in it.

The Qur'an is called a guide because within it are proofs and explanations of religion that are greatly needed for the well-being of humans in this world and their happiness in the hereafter. The guidance and mercy of Allah can only be felt by those who truly believe and trust in Allah and His Messenger in implementing the contents of the Qur'an.
text.21:
Allah commanded His Messenger to ask the disbelievers of Mecca about their dispute, with the intention of refuting their assumptions. They assumed that Allah would treat them and give them the same reward as He gives to the believers. Would Allah equate those who believe in Him but do not practice His law with those who believe and practice His law? The answer is certainly no, never, as Allah says:

"Not equal are the companions of the Fire and the companions of Paradise. The companions of Paradise - they are the attainers [of success]." (al-Hashr/59: 20)

In other verses, it is explained that those who believe, carry out Allah's commands, and avoid His prohibitions are not the same as the wicked (fasiq), namely those who believe and acknowledge the existence of Allah's commands and prohibitions, but do not carry them out. Allah says:

"Then is one who is a believer like one who is defiantly disobedient? They are not equal." (as-Sajdah/32: 18)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that all the assumptions and suspicions of the disbelievers are incorrect and impossible. Therefore, Muslims should be wary of these assumptions so as not to be influenced by them.
text.22:
Allah explains that the heavens and the earth were created with truth, and have a purpose of creation according to His will. There is not a single thing created by God without a purpose. The purpose of the existence of one creation is to be utilized by another creation, in order to achieve the purpose of that other creation. If an activity has no purpose, then what happens is *la'ib*, a game. The opposite word *bathil*, the opposite of the word *haq*, is often used to explain the same thing, as in the verse below:

And We did not create the heaven and the earth and that between them in play. That is the assumption of those who disbelieve, so woe to those who disbelieve from the Fire. (Shad/38:27)

As we witness, the physical properties of the earth, such as mass, structure, temperature, and so on, are so precise for life. However, those properties alone are not enough to enable life on earth; another important factor is the composition of the atmosphere [see Surah Ibrahim/14:19 and Surah al-Jathiyah/45:3].

There is no other power that can change the will of Allah. Such a provision applies to all of His creations in accordance with His justice and *sunnah*. Among Allah's justice is giving a fitting reward to His servants for their deeds and actions on the Day of Judgment.

Whoever does good deeds will receive his reward in accordance with the provisions that He has established, and likewise, whoever does evil deeds will receive a reward commensurate with his evil deeds.

Why is it said that giving a fitting reward is in accordance with Allah's justice? Because Allah created humans as His creatures, equipped with the tendency and ability to do good and do evil. Both or one of these two potentials can develop in a person. Its development is largely determined by circumstances, environment, and time. In addition, Allah has bestowed upon humans intellect. With their intellect, humans have the ability to assess the stimuli that influence their actions and behavior. Before someone decides to take an attitude to do something or not to do it, there is turmoil within themselves in considering and determining a choice, which attitude or action will be taken from the two actions.

At such moments, humans are given the freedom to choose between good and evil. In such turmoil, the human soul experiences pressures called psychological pressures. If he chooses and decides to do a good deed, then that deed occurs based on his own choice. If he chooses to make a decision to do evil, then that too happens because of his own choice. Such moments are the moments that determine whether he intentionally does something or he does not do it intentionally. And also distinguish between actions that are done; whether the action is done consciously or not. That is why it is said that Allah's reward to His servant is in accordance with his deeds and actions, that is a picture of Allah's justice.
text.23:
Muqatil said that this verse was revealed in connection with the conversation between Abu Jahal and al-Walid bin al-Mugirah. One night, Abu Jahal was performing tawaf at the Baitullah with Walid. The two were discussing the state of Prophet Muhammad. Abu Jahal said, "By Allah, I actually know that Muhammad is a truthful person." Al-Walid said to him, "Leave it be, what do you care and what is the reason for your opinion?" Abu Jahal replied, "O Abu Abdisy Syams, we used to call him truthful, honest, and trustworthy in his youth, but after he matured and his intellect was complete, we call him a liar and a traitor. By Allah, I actually know that he is truthful." Al-Walid said, "What is preventing you from affirming and believing in his call?" Abu Jahal replied, "Later, the girls of Quraysh will gossip that I am a follower of the orphan of Abu Talib, even though I am from the highest tribe. By Al-Lata and Al-Uzza, I will never be his follower." Then this verse was revealed.

Furthermore, in this verse, Allah explains the condition of the disbelievers of Mecca who are drowning in evil deeds. All that they do is caused by the promptings of their desires because they have been seduced by the deception of Satan. There are no longer any values of truth that underlie their behavior and actions. What is good according to their desires is what they do. It is as if they consider their desires as gods whose commands they must follow.

They have forgotten that their presence in this fleeting world has a purpose and goal. There is a mission that they must carry, which is to be Allah's caliphs on earth. They have wasted the position that Allah has given them as the best of His creatures in form and having the best abilities. They do not realize that they must be held accountable for all their actions to Allah in the future and that Allah will repay every deed with a fitting reward. This is what is meant by Allah's saying:

"So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it." (az-Zalzalah/99: 7-8)

Actually, the desires that exist in humans are an invaluable gift that Allah has given to humans. In addition to giving humans intellect and religion so that with both, humans can control their desires. If someone controls their desires according to sound reasoning and does not contradict the guidance of religion, then such a person has acted in accordance with their fitrah (natural disposition). But if someone indulges their desires without sound reasoning and no longer guided by the demands of religion, then that person has been enslaved by their desires. This means that they have deviated from their fitrah and fallen into error.

Based on the above explanation, in following their desires, humans are divided into two groups. The first group is the group that can control their desires; they are the people who are pious. While the second group is the people who are controlled by their desires. They are the sinners and always wallowing in the mud of evil.

Ibn 'Abbas said, "Every time Allah mentions desires in the Qur'an, every time He condemns them." Allah says:

"And if We had willed, We could have elevated him thereby, but he adhered [instead] to the earth and followed his own desire. So his example is like that of a dog: if you chase him, he pants, or if you leave him, he [still] pants. That is the example of the people who deny Our signs. So relate the stories that perhaps they will give thought." (al-A'raf/7: 176)

In another verse:

"And do not follow [your own] desire, as it will lead you astray from the way of Allah." (shad/38: 26)

In this verse, Allah praises those who can control their desires and promises them a place of return full of pleasure. Allah says:

"But as for he who feared the position of his Lord and restrained himself from [following] desire, Then indeed, Paradise will be [his] refuge." (an-Nazi'at/79: 40-41)

Many hadith of the Prophet saw condemn those who indulge their desires. Narrated by 'Abdullah bin 'Amr bin 'As that the Prophet saw said.

"None of you truly believes until his desire is in accordance with what I have brought (guidance)." (Riwayat al-Khathib al-Bagdadi)

Syaddad bin Aus narrated a hadith from the Prophet saw:

‡)

"The intelligent person is the one who controls his desires and works for the benefit of the afterlife. But the unjust person is the one who indulges his desires and hopes for something impossible from Allah." (Riwayat at-Tirmidhi and Ibnu Majah)

A person who always indulges his desires usually loses control of himself. That is why he falls into error because he does not want to pay attention to the guidance given to him, and as a result of the evil deeds he has done because of indulging his desires.

The condition of a person who indulges his desires is likened to a person whose heart is locked shut so that he is no longer able to judge what is good and what is bad, and like a person whose ears are blocked so that he is no longer able to pay attention to the signs of Allah's power that are in the heavens and on the earth, and like a person whose eyes are closed and cannot see and know the truth of the existence of Allah, the Creator of all things.

Furthermore, Allah commands His Messenger not to justify the attitude of the disbelievers of Mecca by saying that there is no power that will give guidance other than Allah after they have strayed from the straight path.

At the end of this verse, Allah reminds them why they do not take lessons from the universe, the events in themselves, and the torment that befell previous nations as proof that Allah is All-Powerful and worthy of worship.
text.24:
In this verse, Allah explains the denial of the polytheists regarding the Day of Resurrection. According to their belief, life exists only in this world. They are born in this world and die in this world, and that is the end of everything, and the same happened to their ancestors. According to them, what causes death and destruction of everything is the change of time. From their opinion, it can be concluded that they deny the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection.

This statement is reinforced by the customs of the Jahiliyyah Arabs, namely when they were struck by disaster or misfortune, the words would escape from their mouths, "Oh, woe to time!" They cursed time because, according to them, time was the source of all misfortunes.

In a Qudsi hadith from Abu Hurairah, the Messenger of Allah said:

Allah said, "Man has hurt Me by saying, 'O wretched time.' So let none of you say 'wretched time' because I am (the Creator and Controller of) time. I alternate night and day, and if I willed, I could seize them both." (Narrated by Muslim)

Then Allah regrets the attitude of the polytheists of Mecca which was not based on correct knowledge. Allah states that they have absolutely no knowledge whatsoever about matters concerning time. Their opinion is based only on conjecture and speculation.
text.25:
In this verse, Allah explains and affirms that their opinion is truly based on mere conjecture and suspicion, which leads to the denial of the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection. When the verses of Allah containing explanations about the proofs of the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection are recited to them, they refuse to understand the explanations presented, and they also challenge the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to bring the dead back to life. Only if the Messenger of Allah can do that, will they believe.

From their attitude, it can be concluded that they are truly controlled by their desires, no longer using their minds properly, so they refuse to accept all the truth conveyed by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), that the Day of Resurrection will come at the appointed time, which is after all living humans are killed and the universe and everything in it are destroyed. However, this does not make them understand and acknowledge it.
text.26:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to explain to the polytheists of Mecca that Allah is the One who has the power to give life and cause death to His creatures. Previously, they did not exist and were inanimate objects. Then, by the power of Allah, they were made living beings in the world for a determined period. When that determined time arrives, they are caused to die. Then they are resurrected on the Day of Judgment to be held accountable for all the deeds they have done during their life in the world.

Allah affirms that the occurrence of the Day of Judgment is a certain event, without the slightest doubt. If Allah has the power to give life and cause death, then surely He also has the power to revive and reassemble the parts of their bodies that have been destroyed and scattered into the earth. Repeating an action is easier than creating it for the first time. And for Allah, no action is difficult.

At the end of this verse, Allah regrets why most of the polytheists do not believe in the truth of the Day of Resurrection and continue to deny it, arguing that a person who has died, whose body has been destroyed and mixed with the earth, whose bones have been scattered, cannot possibly live again. Allah says:

And indeed, the Hour is coming; there is no doubt about it; and indeed, Allah will resurrect those in the graves. (al-hajj/22: 7)
text.27: Allah explains that the One who possesses power in the heavens and the earth is Allah. There is nothing that exceeds His power, which operates according to His will. There is no ruler other than Him, and there are no other gods worthy of worship besides Him. His power encompasses the entire universe; the world and the hereafter. Allah also has power at the time the world ends and the hereafter begins. At that time, people will be resurrected from their graves. All people will be driven to the Padang Mahsyar (the Gathering Place) to face judgment. At that time, their deeds will be examined meticulously. Each person will receive a record of their deeds during their life in the world, which was made meticulously by the angels who record deeds. On that day, the gloom of the disbelievers who deny the truth of Allah's verses will be apparent. That gloom will turn into immense misery and suffering when they are dragged into Hell (Jahanam), where they will show their regret, but that regret will be of no use anymore.
text.28:
In this verse, Allah explains the state of mankind on the Day of Judgment and the terror of the chaos while awaiting the decisive moments, namely:

1. On that day, mankind will kneel and prostrate before the Lord of all the worlds to receive the reckoning of their deeds and to receive the final judgment that will be determined upon them.

2. On that day, they will be called to see their records made by the angels. Then they will examine whether any of their deeds have not been recorded or whether something has been recorded but does not correspond to what they have done. If their recorded deeds are in accordance with what is commanded by the religion brought by their messengers, then they will obtain happiness and good fortune, while if they do not conform to the commands and violate many religious prohibitions, then they will obtain misfortune and punishment in hell. Allah says:

And the earth (the Plain of Assembly) will shine with the light (of justice) of its Lord, and the record [of deeds] will be placed, and the prophets and witnesses will be brought forward, and judgment will be passed among them in truth, and they will not be wronged. (az-Zumar/39: 69)

In another verse, Allah says:

And the record [of deeds] will be placed [open], and you will see the criminals fearful of that within it, and they will say, "Oh, woe to us! What is this record that leaves nothing small or great except that it has enumerated it?" And they will find what they did present [before them]. And your Lord does injustice to no one. (al-Kahf/18: 49)

At that time, people will receive a call. They will be informed that on that day they will receive recompense for their respective deeds with a fitting reward.
text.29:
Allah declares His word to all of mankind that the books containing records of deeds are true books, without any errors in them, made on the basis of the command of Allah the Almighty, which serves as the basis for consideration in determining decisions for mankind.

Allah also states that while a person is alive in the world, recorders of deeds have been deployed, both good and bad deeds. These records are infallible because they are made with high precision as evidence whose truth cannot be doubted.
text.30:
Then Allah explains the state of those who believe and do righteous deeds. They will receive a reward commensurate with their deeds. They are among the servants of Allah who receive an abundance of His mercy.

What is meant by Allah's mercy in this verse is Paradise. This is in accordance with the meaning of the hadith narrated by Abu Hurairah:

…)

Indeed, Allah says to Paradise, "You are My mercy. Through you, I bestow My affection upon whom I will." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that Paradise is the happiness that will be achieved by those who believe because of its abundant blessings that will be felt by its inhabitants.
text.31:
In this verse, Allah explains the state of those who deny His Oneness. They are constantly subjected to ridicule and humiliation because an apostle of Allah has come to them, reciting His verses, but they are arrogant and stubborn.

Therefore, they will feel Allah's humiliating punishment because of the sins they have committed. At that moment, they will be speechless because they see the reality that they used to deny.
text.32: In this verse, Allah explains the regret of those who deny the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection. When they were in the world, if they were told about the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection, they considered the news of the Day of Resurrection to be strange and impossible. For them, it was impossible to resurrect the dead whose bones had scattered and whose entire bodies had been destroyed into the earth. But later, after they face reality and are confronted with a terrifying torment, only then will they regret their past attitudes and actions which were solely based on assumptions and presumptions, not based on knowledge and belief in Allah, the All-Powerful Ruler of the Universe.
text.33: Then Allah explains the state of the polytheists when their evil deeds have been clearly revealed. They stammered, overwhelmed by the immense responsibility. They felt afraid seeing their accumulated sins that they had to atone for with the torment of hellfire, which they greatly feared. They also realized at that moment that no one could defend them; their power during their time in the world, their abundant wealth, their descendants, their conspiring friends, and so on, all were meaningless at that time. The only option they could take at that time was to await the decision and resign themselves to receiving Allah's punishment.
text.34:
In this verse, Allah explains the mockery, humiliation, and torment that they will endure on the Day of Judgment. On that day, Allah will not heed their cries and tears, their lamentations and regrets, because everything they experience is truly a retribution that is balanced with their deeds in the world.

In the world, they oppressed and slandered the innocent, legalized the unlawful for the benefit of themselves and their groups; Allah will give them a fitting reward for all their deeds in the Hereafter.

If Allah ignores them because of the arrogance and pride they have displayed, as well as the inhumane attitudes they have practiced, then such an attitude is a just recompense in accordance with His justice.
text.35:
In this verse, Allah explains why the disbelievers must receive such terrible torment and punishment. The reasons are:

1.  Because during their lives in the world, they mocked the verses of Allah that were conveyed to them through His Messenger. This attitude is considered one of arrogance and pride. They also sought to undermine the faith that had permeated the hearts of the Muslims with various pretexts and methods.

2.  They were deceived by the pleasures of worldly life, so they forgot the Hereafter, which is the ultimate goal of human life.

That is why, when Allah issues His decree, there is no possibility for them to escape the punishment, and there is no forgiveness for them.
text.36:
These two verses are the closing verses of Surah al-Jatsiyah. In these verses, Allah mentions some of His attributes that are related to the basis for decision-making on the Day of Judgment, namely:

1. He is the Most Praiseworthy, therefore all praise belongs to Him. This expression gives the understanding that all blessings that humans obtain during their life in the world originate from Allah so that humans can carry out their duties as His caliphs on earth, not to act arbitrarily and indulge their desires. These two verses are the concluding verses of Surah al-Jatsiyah. In these verses, Allah mentions some of His attributes that are related to the foundations of decision-making on the Day of Judgment, namely:

1. He is the Most Praiseworthy, therefore all praise belongs to Him. This expression gives the understanding that all blessings that humans obtain during their life in the world come from Allah so that humans can carry out their duty as His caliphs on earth, not to act arbitrarily and indulge their desires. If humans do not give thanks for that blessing and do not use that blessing as it should be, then surely that person will receive His wrath and punishment.

2. Allah is the All-Powerful, He controls the universe. This statement gives the understanding that everything in the heavens and on earth is under His control. He controls the world and the hereafter.

3. He is the Most Great, because greatness and arrogance belong only to Allah in the heavens and on earth, and His power is above all powers.

4. He is the All-Mighty, His decisions cannot be rejected, cannot be changed by anyone, and no one can match His power.

5. He is the All-Wise. Meaning: Allah, in establishing His commands to all of His creatures, is always accompanied by rules, calculations, and success, and it will certainly happen according to what He wills.
